Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Story: I stared at the overflowing laundry basket, socks and shirts tumbling out onto the hallway floor. My husband had mentioned, not unkindly, that he was out of clean work shirts. I knew he expected me to help keep the house running smoothly, and I wanted to do my part. But my phone buzzed with a message from the plant manager: “A few machines are running hot—can you check them ASAP?” I pictured the whirring gears, the smell of oil, the risk of a costly breakdown if I didn’t get there soon. My mind raced between the two worlds—at home, the quiet expectation to fold and sort, to be present and supportive; at work, the urgent demand to prevent disaster, to be the reliable fixer. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each one needing me now, each one silently accusing me of neglect. My hands hovered over the laundry, but my thoughts were already with the machines, and I wondered how I could possibly be enough for both.
